questions.text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his parents because of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting over the past week. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but he often spits up or refuses to eat. He has not had a cough, fever, or bloody stools. The patient was born at term by cesarean delivery and had his first bowel movement 2 days after delivery. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the 50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows that the patient has small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The abdomen is distended. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In adults, a CT scan of the abdomen is a common diagnostic test for patients with acute abdominal pain or severe abdominal distention. However, in children in general and even more so in newborns such as this boy at 3 weeks of age, CT scans should be avoided whenever possible because of the exposure to ionizing radiation and the significant risk of long-term complications (e.g., radiation-related cancers). Alternative imaging techniques such as ultrasonography and/or MRI are almost always preferred. Abdominal CT scans are not indicated for the diagnostic workup of HD.

B) INCORRECT:

Transabdominal ultrasonography can be used to assess other potential causes of abdominal distention or congenital malformations of the abdominal cavity (e.g., duodenal atresia). While findings on abdominal ultrasonography may support the diagnosis (e.g., dilated colonic segments), given its poor positive predictive value, ultrasound does not play an important role in the diagnosis of HD. It would not be an appropriate confirmatory test for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A barium enema may be used to determine the length of the aganglionic segment prior to surgery in infants with suspected HD. Barium enema is also useful for excluding HD in patients with a low clinical suspicion of the disease. However, it has a low sensitivity and specificity for HD and is, therefore, not an appropriate confirmatory test.

D) INCORRECT:

Anorectal manometry is a useful screening test in children > 1 month of age with suspected HD. However, because the developing anorectal sphincter does not reach a stable resting pressure until approx. 1 month of age, anorectal manometry is not the best diagnostic test for this 3-week-old patient. In addition, accurate evaluation in anorectal manometry requires precise placement of sensors, which is challenging with a newborn patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis is the gold standard test for diagnosing cystic fibrosis (CF). Approx.10% of children with CF have meconium ileus, which manifests with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distention, and possibly bilious vomiting. While the clinical presentation is similar to that seen in this patient, the findings of explosive stool release upon rectal examination and the association with Down syndrome are more suggestive of HD.

F) CORRECT:

Rectal biopsy is the gold standard confirmatory test for suspected HD. It can be performed either as a full-thickness biopsy, carried out under general anesthesia, or as a rectal suction biopsy, directly at the bedside, sparing the patient the need to undergo general anesthesia. If the biopsy shows an absence of ganglion cells in an adequate tissue sample, HD is confirmed. A normal biopsy result taken from a correct site (i.e., 2 cm proximal to the dentate line) virtually rules out HD.

If HD is confirmed, the aganglionic segment of the colon is resected and anastomosed, either in a one-stage operation or, less commonly, as a two-stage surgery in which a diverting colostomy is performed to decompress the dilated bowel, followed by definitive anastomosis of the bowel loops.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newborn

A massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.

Yellow overlay: gastric bubble
questions.hint: This newborn has features of Down syndrome and was noted at birth to have late passage of meconium, which raises concern for Hirschsprung disease (HD). The current symptoms of poor feeding and bilious vomiting, physical findings of abdominal distention and explosive stool release upon rectal examination, and the presence of a dilated colonic segment proximal to an empty segment on x-ray further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: One week after delivery, a 3550-g (7-lb 13-oz) male newborn has multiple episodes of bilious vomiting and abdominal distention. He passed urine 14 hours after delivery and had his first bowel movement 3 days after delivery. He was born at term to a 31-year-old woman. Pregnancy was uncomplicated and the mother received adequate prenatal care. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 50/min. Examination shows a distended abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Digital rectal examination shows increased anal sphincter tone and an empty rectal vault. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the underlying cause of these findings?

choices.text: Defective migration of neural crest cells
Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum
Invagination of bowel loop into adjacent bowel loop
Hemorrhagic inflammation of the intestinal wall
Failed recanalization of the fetal duodenum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Defective migration of neural crest cells from the proximal to the distal bowel is the underlying mechanism of Hirschsprung disease. This phenomenon typically results in an aganglionic rectum and distal sigmoid, which prevents the internal anal sphincter from relaxing in response to rectal distension, leading to intestinal obstruction and megacolon. The diagnosis is confirmed with a rectal biopsy, which usually shows aganglionosis and/or hypertrophy of parasympathetic fibers.

See “Differential diagnosis of intestinal obstruction in neonates” table.
Image Description:

The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

B) INCORRECT:

Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum is responsible for jejunal atresia, which can also manifest with bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and delayed meconium passage. However, symptoms usually appear in feeding infants within 24 hours of birth and an x-ray of the abdomen would show a triple bubble sign.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (A and B: supine) of two neonates with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting

Dilatation of the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum (A) is characteristic of the triple bubble sign of jejunal atresia. Multiple dilated bowel loops (B) may alternatively be seen in jejunal atresia, and the number of loops may increase in conjunction with a more distal location of the atresia.

1: gastric air-fluid level; 2: duodenal air-fluid level; 3: jejunal air-fluid level

C) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the CFTR gene is the underlying cause of cystic fibrosis, which may result in abdominal distention and bilious vomiting due to intestinal obstruction as a result of thickened, inspissated meconium within the distal ileum (meconium ileus). However, although delayed (3 days after delivery), this patient already passed meconium, and bowel sounds would typically be hyperactive in mechanical bowel obstruction. Furthermore, an x-ray in meconium ileus would typically show small bowel distention or a soap-bubble appearance (Neuhauser sign), rather than a distended descending colon, as seen here.
Image Description:

Barium enema (AP view) of a neonate with meconium ileus

Multiple dilated gas-filled loops of small bowel are visible and opaque barium contrast outlines a microcolon (sections of microcolon indicated by green outlines). The findings are consistent with meconium ileus.

Contrast is also seen in multiple locations within the peritoneal space (examples indicated by red overlay) as a result of bowel perforation.

Blue overlay: ECG electrodes

D) INCORRECT:

Intussusception is more common in males and may result in abdominal distention, bilious vomiting, and dilated bowel loops on x-ray due to intestinal obstruction. However, the small bowel would be distended (not the large bowel), since intussusception typically occurs at the ileocolic junction, and bowel sounds would be increased. Moreover, intussusception usually occurs between 5 months and 3 years of age; it is extremely rare in the neonatal period. Finally, blood in the rectum is often found on digital rectal examination, which was not the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

Intestinal malrotation may manifest within the first month of life with bilious vomiting and abdominal distention due to intestinal obstruction caused by Ladd bands or by a midgut volvulus. However, bowel sounds would likely be increased and an x-ray would show a double bubble sign, or multiple air-fluid levels proximal to the site of obstruction, in contrast to the distended descending colon in this patient.
Image Description:

Fluoroscopy (upper GI series)

The distal duodenum and proximal jejunum has a spiral configuration (green overlay) and fail to cross the midline into the left upper quadrant. This appearance, referred to as the corkscrew sign, is produced by the twisting of small bowel loops on a shortened mesentery.

The corkscrew sign is characteristic of intestinal malrotation with midgut volvulus.

F) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhagic inflammation of the intestinal wall is seen in necrotizing enterocolitis, which may manifest with abdominal distention and bilious vomiting shortly after birth, However, an x-ray would typically show bowel wall edema, pneumatosis intestinalis, and/or free air within the abdomen (due to perforation of a viscus). Also, patients typically have a history of bloody diarrhea (unlike this neonate, who had delayed meconium passage) and the child would appear seriously ill with cardiopulmonary instability. Moreover, this patient lacks the risk factors commonly associated with necrotizing enterocolitis, such as preterm birth and neonatal asphyxia.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view; supine) of a neonate

Multiple distended bowel loops in the right hemiabdomen are accompanied by small lucencies indicating the presence of intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis).

Pneumatosis intestinalis is a feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. It can appear as bubbly (green overlay), curvilinear (yellow overlay), or linear (red overlay) lucencies on an abdominal radiograph.

G) INCORRECT:

Failed recanalization of the fetal duodenum results in duodenal atresia, which would also manifest with bilious vomiting and delayed meconium passage. However, abdominal distention is typically not as prominent, and symptoms are usually evident on the first day after birth with the initiation of feeds. Additionally, the prenatal period is often complicated by polyhydramnios, and an x-ray of the abdomen would show a double bubble sign and absence of gas in the small and large intestine.
Image Description:

X-ray of the abdomen

Dilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

H) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which is more common in males, may result in vomiting in the neonatal period. However, the vomiting is nonbilious, projectile, occurs following feeds, and usually begins 2 weeks after birth. An x-ray of the abdomen would show a distended stomach with minimal distention of the bowels. Other clinical features include decreased soiling of diapers (due to decreased urine output), as well as a hypertrophic “olive” in the epigastric region and/or a gastric peristaltic wave on examination.
questions.hint: Abdominal distention, multiple episodes of bilious vomiting, and a dilated large bowel loop suggest lower intestinal obstruction. The delayed passage of meconium, empty rectal vault, and a narrow sigmoid colon with a dilated segment on x-ray support the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. Patients with this condition may also present with a squirt sign.

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of abdominal distention, inconsolable crying, and 3 episodes of bilious vomiting since the previous evening. He was delivered at home at 40 weeks' gestation by a trained midwife. He has not passed meconium. Physical examination shows abdominal distention, a tight anal sphincter, and an explosive passage of air and feces on removal of the examining finger. Abnormal development of which of the following best explains this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The muscularis propria and adventitia are the outermost layers of the GI tract. The muscularis propria provides sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation, as well as motor innervation to the smooth muscle of the GI tract. The adventitia is the most superficial layer of the portion of the GI tract lying outside the peritoneal cavity (e.g., colon, esophagus) and is made up of connective tissue that acts to protect and create attachments to neighboring structures. However, Hirschsprung disease does not involve a joint defect of the muscularis propria and adventitia.

B) INCORRECT:

The muscularis mucosae is the outermost layer of the GI mucosa, and the serosa is the outermost layer of the portion of the GI tract within the peritoneal cavity. The muscularis mucosae allows the mucosa to move, which facilitates glandular secretion and absorption. The serosa coats the intestines and secretes serous fluid that protects the GI tract against frictional damage, which might occur during movement within the abdomen. However, Hirschsprung disease involves other layers of the GI tract.

C) INCORRECT:

The epithelium and lamina propria are the innermost layers of the GI tract mucosa. The epithelium contains glands that secrete digestive enzymes and also serves to absorb nutrients and water. It is attached via the lamina propria to the interior of the GI tract wall. However, Hirschsprung disease involves other layers of the GI tract.

D) CORRECT:

The submucosa normally contains the Meissner plexus, while the muscularis externa contains the Auerbach plexus. In Hirschsprung disease, these two plexuses are absent at the anorectal line. Hirschsprung disease is caused by defective migration of plexus ganglion cell precursors (neural crest cells), which ordinarily migrate to the distal colon during fetal development. Without the plexuses, peristalsis is uncoordinated, motility is slow, and relaxation is impeded, resulting in excessive contraction of intestinal muscles, constipation, and obstruction. A biopsy of the distal colon showing absent ganglion cells is diagnostic.
Image Description:

The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

E) INCORRECT:

The epithelium is the innermost layer of the GI mucosa, and the submucosa lies just outside of the GI mucosa. The epithelium contains glands that secrete digestive enzymes and also serves to absorb nutrients and water. The submucosa provides parasympathetic innervation to glands and is responsible for secretomotor activity. However, Hirschsprung disease does not involve a joint defect of the epithelium and submucosa.

F) INCORRECT:

The muscularis mucosae and lamina propria are the two outermost layers of the GI mucosa. The muscularis mucosae allows the mucosa to move, which facilitates glandular secretion and absorption and the lamina propria is the attachment site for the GI epithelium. However, Hirschsprung disease involves other layers of the GI tract.
questions.hint: This newborn's bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, failure to pass meconium in the first 48 hours of life, tight anal sphincter, and explosive passage of stool on examination are consistent with Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of insufficient weight gain and worsening constipation for the past 2 months. The father reports that since birth she has had infrequent bowel movements, but currently only has one bowel movement every 14 days and passes small, narrow stools. Treatment with prune juice has been unsuccessful. The girl was born at term by home birth; pregnancy was uncomplicated and the mother received adequate prenatal care. The girl did not undergo newborn screening. The father does not remember when she passed her first stool after birth. Until the introduction of solids at the age of 6 months, she had been exclusively breastfed. Now she eats three solid meals of a balanced diet and nurses twice daily. Her mother has celiac disease. The patient is at the 3rd percentile for weight and the 10th percentile for length. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Digital rectal examination shows an empty ampulla. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anorectal manometry is a useful screening test in children > 1 month of age with suspected Hirschsprung disease (HD). While most cases of HD manifest in the neonatal period with symptoms of distal intestinal obstruction (e.g., delayed passage of meconium, bilious vomiting), patients with mild disease (e.g., ultrashort-segment HD) may present later in childhood with growth faltering, chronic constipation with the passage of small diameter stools, and an empty ampulla on digital rectal examination. In a patient with HD, anorectal manometry shows an absent relaxation reflex of the internal anal sphincter after stretching of the rectum. The diagnosis is confirmed by a rectal biopsy that shows aganglionosis, increased acetylcholinesterase activity, and/or hyperplasia of parasympathetic fibers. Infants with HD usually require surgical correction (i.e., removal of the affected segment of the colon and attachment of the normal ganglionic intestinal ends). Those with mild disease may be treated conservatively with diet, stool softeners, and laxatives.
Image Description:

The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

B) INCORRECT:

Pharmacotherapy with laxatives (e.g., lactulose) is used in infants with functional constipation who do not respond to nonpharmacologic measures such as prune juice. Functional constipation is the most common cause of constipation in infancy and childhood and may occur after the introduction of solids into the diet. However, infants with this condition typically have large stools rather than small, narrow stools, and rectal examination often shows a fecal mass in the rectal ampulla. Moreover, this patient has alarming signs (e.g., early onset of constipation, growth faltering, empty ampulla on rectal examination), which require further evaluation before initiating therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis is the gold standard test for diagnosing cystic fibrosis (CF), which can manifest with constipation and growth faltering. This patient did not undergo newborn screening, which includes screening for CF, so an early diagnosis of this condition might have been missed. However, she has no other signs or symptoms suggestive of cystic fibrosis (e.g., persistent pulmonary infections, pancreatic insufficiency). Moreover, her history of small, narrow stools and rectal examination findings suggest a different diagnosis, for which another step in management is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

A gluten-free diet is indicated for children with celiac disease, which can manifest with constipation and growth faltering in a 12-month-old child. The mother's history of celiac disease puts the patient at high risk for developing the condition. However, the history of small, narrow stools and rectal examination findings suggest a different diagnosis, for which another step in management is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid function tests are used to evaluate for acquired or congenital hypothyroidism, which can manifest with growth faltering and constipation. This patient did not undergo newborn screening, which includes the measurement of TSH levels, so an early diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism may have been missed. However, during the first year of life, patients with congenital hypothyroidism typically also develop features such as lethargy, hoarse cry, puffed face, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and hypotonia. Moreover, the passage of small, narrow stools and an empty ampulla on rectal examination is not associated with hypothyroidism.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition frequently present with delayed passage of meconium at birth.

questions.text:
A full-term male infant, 36 hours old, is evaluated in the newborn nursery for one episode of dark-green emesis with an increase in abdominal girth. Before this episode, he was breastfeeding well and had no abnormalities on physical examination. He has not yet passed meconium.
On examination, he is fussy and cries. His abdomen is distended but not tense, and bowel sounds are present. The remainder of his examination is normal.
A radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has bilious emesis, abdominal distention, failure to pass meconium, and a radiograph showing gaseous distention of multiple loops of bowel. This constellation of findings is concerning for a distal large-bowel obstruction, such as that seen in Hirschsprung disease, cystic fibrosis (meconium ileus), or imperforate anus. Given that the patient's external examination is normal, Hirschsprung disease is high on the differential diagnosis. One should also consider meconium ileus as a presentation of cystic fibrosis. For infants with cystic fibrosis, a plain radiograph may reveal dilated loops of bowel, calcifications, and sometimes perforation.

Almost all healthy newborns (94% to 99%) pass meconium within 24 hours after birth, and 100% do so within 48 hours. In contrast, only 6% of newborns with Hirschsprung disease pass meconium within 24 hours, and 37% to 54% do so within 48 hours; 64% present with emesis. Meconium ileus occurs in up to 20% of patients with cystic fibrosis and can be the presenting condition during the newborn period.

The most appropriate next step in care for a neonate with distal bowel obstruction is a contrast enema. Given that this patient’s radiograph suggests distal obstruction and there are no calcifications, Hirschsprung disease is the more likely diagnosis.

Hirschsprung disease is a congenital intestinal neuropathy that is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells extending from the rectum proximally for a variable distance. The incidence is 1 in 5000 live births. The disease often manifests as failure to pass meconium within 48 hours after birth and can progress to abdominal distention and vomiting, typically bilious in nature. Rectal suction biopsy can confirm the presence of Hirschsprung disease definitively. Sweat testing can confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.

Key learning point: A newborn presenting with abdominal distention, vomiting, and failure to pass meconium within 36 hours after birth should be evaluated with a contrast enema.

B) INCORRECT:

A glycerin suppository can be helpful for simple constipation, but this is highly unlikely in a newborn and would not be associated with bilious emesis. This patient requires diagnostic imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

An upper gastrointestinal contrast series is useful in the evaluation of intestinal malrotation, which should be considered in any neonate with bilious emesis. Malrotation with volvulus is a surgical emergency and requires rapid action to prevent extensive, life-threatening loss of bowel. Abdominal radiographs will show a dilated stomach and paucity of gas beyond the volvulus. This patient's radiograph is not consistent with this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Partially hydrolyzed formula is used for infants who have a milk protein allergy, but this usually manifests with bloody stools (not constipation or failure to pass meconium), and it would be very unusual in the immediate period after birth.

E) INCORRECT:

Given this patient's symptoms of bowel obstruction and radiographic evidence of bowel distention, he should have all oral nutrition withheld. Offering him formula or breast milk at this time would likely make him more ill. His mother should be advised to express and store breast milk, to establish her milk supply while the infant is being evaluated and treated.

questions.text:
A 10-day-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for poor feeding and persistent constipation. The infant did not pass meconium until 48 hours after birth and has had recurring episodes of abdominal distension. On examination, he appears mildly irritable but afebrile. The abdomen is distended without localized tenderness. A digital rectal exam reveals an empty rectal vault, and upon withdrawal of the examining finger, there is a sudden expulsion of foul-smelling stool and gas. The newborn metabolic screening was unremarkable, and there are no visible anal anomalies (see image).
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Functional constipation lacks early-life red flags such as delayed meconium passage beyond 24 hours. The explosive release of stool and gas after a digital rectal exam suggests a motility disturbance, not typical of functional constipation, which is usually behavioral.

B) CORRECT:

Hirschsprung disease results from the congenital absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon and rectum, leading to functional obstruction due to impaired peristalsis. Clinical manifestations include delayed passage of meconium beyond 48 hours, chronic constipation, and abdominal distension. The digital rectal examination reveals an empty rectal vault, followed by explosive expulsion of stool and gas, indicating a buildup of contents proximal to the aganglionic segment. This condition arises from the failure of neural crest cell migration during embryonic development, explaining the typical presentation in neonates.

Key learning point: Hirschsprung disease is characterized by an empty rectum on examination and the passage of a large amount of stool and gas after rectal examination, known as the 'squirt sign'.

C) INCORRECT:

Intussusception typically presents acutely with colicky pain, vomiting, and bloody stools, unlike the more chronic symptoms seen here. The explosive stool release on rectal exam suggests impaired motility, not the bowel telescoping characteristic of intussusception.

D) INCORRECT:

Meconium ileus, often linked to cystic fibrosis, presents with delayed meconium passage and small bowel obstruction. However, normal newborn metabolic screening and absence of proximal intestinal distension or bilious vomiting make this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A neonate has not passed meconium by 48 hours and exhibits abdominal distension. Biopsy confirms Hirschsprung disease. What is the most appropriate definitive management?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the aganglionic segment with pull-through

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hirschsprung disease is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexuses of a bowel segment, leading to functional obstruction. This condition manifests in neonates as failure to pass meconium and abdominal distension. Diagnosis is confirmed by rectal biopsy showing absence of ganglion cells. Definitive management involves surgical resection of the aganglionic segment and a pull-through procedure, which restores bowel continuity and function by connecting normally innervated bowel to the anus.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for Hirschsprung disease is surgical resection of the affected bowel segment, as it addresses the underlying cause of the condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Rectal botulinum toxin injections temporarily relax the internal anal sphincter but do not address the absence of ganglion cells in Hirschsprung disease. The condition requires surgical intervention to remove the aganglionic segment and restore normal bowel function.

C) INCORRECT:

Long-term stool softeners are ineffective in Hirschsprung disease, as the condition involves a congenital absence of ganglion cells, leading to a fixed mechanical obstruction. Stool softeners do not address the lack of peristalsis in the affected bowel segment.

D) INCORRECT:

Serial rectal dilatations may temporarily relieve obstruction by widening the anal canal, but they do not address the absence of ganglion cells in Hirschsprung disease. The condition involves a fixed contraction of the bowel segment that cannot be resolved by dilatation, and this approach does not restore peristalsis.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old newborn presents with increasing abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. The newborn has not passed meconium since birth. On examination, the abdomen is tense (see report).
Barium enema: Narrow distal colon and proximal colonic dilation
Which of the following tests is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hirschsprung disease results from the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon due to failed migration of neural crest cells. This leads to a lack of the submucosal (Meissner) and myenteric (Auerbach) plexuses, causing functional obstruction. A rectal biopsy is the definitive diagnostic test, as it allows histopathological examination to confirm the absence of ganglion cells and the presence of hypertrophied nerve fibers. This histological confirmation is crucial for differentiating Hirschsprung disease from other causes of neonatal intestinal obstruction.

Key learning point: In infants with symptoms suggestive of Hirschsprung disease, a rectal biopsy is the most definitive diagnostic test to confirm the absence of ganglion cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Anorectal manometry assesses anorectal physiology by measuring pressures and the rectoanal inhibitory reflex, which is absent in Hirschsprung disease. However, in neonates, the reflex may not be fully developed, leading to false negatives. In addition, accurate evaluation in anorectal manometry requires precise placement of sensors, which is challenging with a newborn patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy allows visualization of the colonic mucosa but cannot assess the submucosal and myenteric layers where ganglion cells reside. In neonates, the procedure is technically challenging and does not provide the histological confirmation needed for diagnosing Hirschsprung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound is useful for assessing solid organs and fluid but cannot evaluate the neuromuscular and histological aspects of the colon. It lacks the resolution to identify the aganglionic segment or assess the intrinsic nerve supply, making it unsuitable for confirming Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: You are seeing a 12-month-old girl who is brought to your clinic due to insufficient weight gain and worsening constipation over the past 2 months. Her father reports that she has had infrequent bowel movements since birth, and now has only one bowel movement every 14 days, passing small, narrow stools. She was exclusively breastfed until solids were introduced at 6 months of age. She is at the 3rd percentile for weight and the 10th percentile for length. On examination, her abdomen is distended, bowel sounds are hypoactive, and digital rectal examination reveals an empty ampulla. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pharmacotherapy with laxatives (e.g., lactulose) is used in infants with functional constipation who do not respond to nonpharmacologic measures such as prune juice. Functional constipation is the most common cause of constipation in infancy and childhood and may occur after the introduction of solids into the diet. However, infants with this condition typically have large stools rather than small, narrow stools, and rectal examination often shows a fecal mass in the rectal ampulla. Moreover, this patient has alarming signs (e.g., early onset of constipation, growth faltering, empty ampulla on rectal examination), which require further evaluation before initiating therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Anorectal manometry is a useful screening test in children > 1 month of age with suspected Hirschsprung disease (HD). While most cases of HD manifest in the neonatal period with symptoms of distal intestinal obstruction (e.g., delayed passage of meconium, bilious vomiting), patients with mild disease (e.g., ultrashort-segment HD) may present later in childhood with growth faltering, chronic constipation with the passage of small diameter stools, and an empty ampulla on digital rectal examination. In a patient with HD, anorectal manometry shows an absent relaxation reflex of the internal anal sphincter after stretching of the rectum. The diagnosis is confirmed by a rectal biopsy that shows aganglionosis, increased acetylcholinesterase activity, and/or hyperplasia of parasympathetic fibers. Infants with HD usually require surgical correction (i.e., removal of the affected segment of the colon and attachment of the normal ganglionic intestinal ends). Those with mild disease may be treated conservatively with diet, stool softeners, and laxatives.

Key learning point: Anorectal manometry is the preferred initial diagnostic test for Hirschsprung disease in children with chronic constipation, growth faltering, and an empty rectal ampulla.
Image Description:

The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

C) INCORRECT:

Quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis is the gold standard test for diagnosing cystic fibrosis (CF), which can manifest with constipation and growth faltering. However, she has no other signs or symptoms suggestive of cystic fibrosis (e.g., persistent pulmonary infections, pancreatic insufficiency). Moreover, her history of small, narrow stools and rectal examination findings suggest a different diagnosis, for which another step in management is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

A gluten-free diet is indicated for children with celiac disease, which can manifest with constipation and growth faltering in a 12-month-old child. However, the history of small, narrow stools and rectal examination findings suggest a different diagnosis, for which another step in management is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid function tests are used to evaluate for acquired or congenital hypothyroidism, which can manifest with growth faltering and constipation. However, during the first year of life, patients with congenital hypothyroidism typically also develop features such as lethargy, hoarse cry, puffed face, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and hypotonia. Moreover, the passage of small, narrow stools and an empty ampulla on rectal examination is not associated with hypothyroidism.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition frequently present with delayed passage of meconium at birth.

questions.text: One week after delivery, you are asked to assess a male newborn who weighs 3550 g and has had multiple episodes of bilious vomiting. He passed urine 14 hours after birth and had his first bowel movement 3 days after delivery. The pregnancy was uncomplicated. His temperature is 37.1°C, pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 50/min. On examination, his abdomen is distended and bowel sounds are hypoactive. Digital rectal examination reveals increased anal sphincter tone and an empty rectal vault. An abdominal x-ray is provided. Which one of the following is the underlying cause of these findings?

choices.text: Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum.
Defective migration of neural crest cells.
Invagination of bowel loop into adjacent bowel loop.
Failed recanalization of the fetal duodenum.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the CFTR gene is the underlying cause of cystic fibrosis, which may result in abdominal distention and bilious vomiting due to intestinal obstruction as a result of thickened, inspissated meconium within the distal ileum (meconium ileus). However, although delayed (3 days after delivery), this patient already passed meconium, and bowel sounds would typically be hyperactive in mechanical bowel obstruction. Furthermore, an x-ray in meconium ileus would typically show small bowel distention or a soap-bubble appearance (Neuhauser sign), rather than a distended descending colon, as seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum is responsible for jejunal atresia, which can also manifest with bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and delayed meconium passage. However, symptoms usually appear in feeding infants within 24 hours of birth and an x-ray of the abdomen would show a triple bubble sign.

C) CORRECT:

Defective migration of neural crest cells from the proximal to the distal bowel is the underlying mechanism of Hirschsprung disease. This phenomenon typically results in an aganglionic rectum and distal sigmoid, which prevents the internal anal sphincter from relaxing in response to rectal distension, leading to intestinal obstruction and megacolon. The diagnosis is confirmed with a rectal biopsy, which usually shows aganglionosis and/or hypertrophy of parasympathetic fibers.

See “Differential diagnosis of intestinal obstruction in neonates” table.

Key learning point: Hirschsprung disease is caused by defective migration of neural crest cells, resulting in aganglionic segments of the colon that lead to functional intestinal obstruction in neonates.
Image Description:

The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

D) INCORRECT:

Intussusception is more common in males and may result in abdominal distention, bilious vomiting, and dilated bowel loops on x-ray due to intestinal obstruction. However, the small bowel would be distended (not the large bowel), since intussusception typically occurs at the ileocolic junction, and bowel sounds would be increased. Moreover, intussusception usually occurs between 5 months and 3 years of age; it is extremely rare in the neonatal period. Finally, blood in the rectum is often found on digital rectal examination, which was not the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

Failed recanalization of the fetal duodenum results in duodenal atresia, which would also manifest with bilious vomiting and delayed meconium passage. However, abdominal distention is typically not as prominent, and symptoms are usually evident on the first day after birth with the initiation of feeds. Additionally, the prenatal period is often complicated by polyhydramnios, and an x-ray of the abdomen would show a double bubble sign and absence of gas in the small and large intestine.
questions.hint: Abdominal distention, multiple episodes of bilious vomiting, and a dilated large bowel loop suggest lower intestinal obstruction. The delayed passage of meconium, empty rectal vault, and a narrow sigmoid colon with a dilated segment on x-ray support the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. Patients with this condition may also present with a squirt sign.

questions.text: A 3-day-old full-term neonate is brought to the emergency department by his parents with a 6-hour history of progressive abdominal distention and bilious vomiting. The infant has not passed meconium since delivery. Physical examination shows a markedly distended abdomen with visible bowel loops. Digital rectal examination shows a tight anal sphincter with an empty rectum, and upon withdrawal of the examining finger, there is explosive release of stool and air. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Abdominal x-ray is the initial diagnostic study for suspected Hirschsprung disease in neonates and typically shows decreased rectal air and dilated proximal colon. Contrast enema is typically also performed as part of the initial workup to identify the transition zone between dilated and narrow bowel segments. These studies help confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes of neonatal intestinal obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Upper gastrointestinal series is used to evaluate for upper intestinal obstruction and malrotation but is not appropriate to assess for suspected distal intestinal obstruction. This patient's clinical presentation suggests involvement of the colon, requiring an alternative diagnostic study.

C) INCORRECT:

While rectal suction biopsy is the definitive diagnostic test to confirm Hirschsprung disease, it is not the initial diagnostic study.

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound is not the recommended initial diagnostic study for suspected Hirschsprung disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Anorectal manometry is reserved for patients with atypical symptoms or when initial imaging studies are inconclusive, but it is not the initial diagnostic approach in neonates with typical Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male neonate is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of watery diarrhea with blood streaks over the past 24 hours. The infant did not pass meconium for the first 48 hours of life. Physical examination shows abdominal distention. Vital signs are BP, 80/30; P, 210; T 38.5°C (101.3°F). Capillary refill is delayed. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Obtain contrast enema to confirm diagnosis
Start oral rehydration therapy and observe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contrast enema is contraindicated in suspected Hirschsprung-associated enterocolitis due to the risk of perforation. The presence of fever and systemic signs suggests HAEC, making contrast studies inappropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This neonate presents with signs of HAEC including fever, lethargy, and systemic illness. HAEC is a life-threatening complication requiring immediate IV fluid resuscitation. Pediatric surgery should be consulted urgently to decide further management. In addition, empiric antibiotics are needed in this critically ill patient.

C) INCORRECT:

While bowel decompression is needed in infants with HAEC, rectal irrigation should only be performed after initial stabilization and under specialist guidance.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral rehydration is inappropriate for a critically ill neonate with signs of HAEC and systemic illness.

E) INCORRECT:

While abdominal x-ray is used in the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease and HAEC, another step is more urgently indicated in this critically ill patient.

questions.text: Two days after delivery, a 3470-g (7-lb 10-oz) newborn has an episode of bilious vomiting. He has not yet passed meconium. He was born at term to a 26-year-old woman; pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a distended abdomen. There is tympany to percussion. Digital rectal examination shows elevated sphincter tone; when the finger is removed, there is an explosive release of stool and air. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a massively dilated colon proximal to a narrowed segment of colon. Which of the following is the underlying cause of these findings?

choices.text: Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa
Telescoping of intestinal segment into itself
Impaired migration of neural crest cells
Failure to restore patency to fetal duodenum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa is seen in necrotizing enterocolitis, which can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious vomiting shortly after birth, However, an x-ray would typically show bowel wall edema, pneumatosis intestinalis, and/or free air within the abdomen (due to intestinal perforation). Also, patients typically have a history of bloody diarrhea (unlike this neonate, who has delayed passage of meconium), and the child would appear seriously ill with cardiopulmonary instability. Moreover, this patient lacks the risk factors commonly associated with necrotizing enterocolitis, such as preterm birth and neonatal asphyxia.

Prolonged intestinal obstruction in Hirschsprung disease can also result in enterocolitis and perforation of the bowel wall.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view; supine) of a neonate

Multiple distended bowel loops in the right hemiabdomen are accompanied by small lucencies indicating the presence of intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis).

Pneumatosis intestinalis is a feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. It can appear as bubbly (green overlay), curvilinear (yellow overlay), or linear (red overlay) lucencies on an abdominal radiograph.

B) INCORRECT:

Intussusception, or telescoping of the proximal intestinal segment into the distal segment, is more common in males and may result in abdominal distention, bilious vomiting, and dilated bowel loops on x-ray due to intestinal obstruction. However, the small bowel would be distended (not the large bowel), since intussusception typically occurs at the ileocolic junction. Moreover, intussusception usually occurs between 5 months and 3 years of age; it is extremely rare in the neonatal period. Finally, blood in the rectum is often found on digital rectal examination, which was not the case here.

C) INCORRECT:

Intestinal malrotation can manifest within the first month of life with bilious vomiting and abdominal distention due to intestinal obstruction caused by Ladd bands or a midgut volvulus. However, x-ray would show a double bubble sign or multiple air-fluid levels proximal to the site of obstruction, in contrast to the distended descending colon seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which is more common in males, may result in vomiting in the neonatal period. However, the vomiting is nonbilious, projectile, occurs following feeds, and usually begins 2–6 weeks after birth. An x-ray of the abdomen would show a distended stomach with minimal distention of the bowels. Other clinical features include decreased soiling of diapers (due to decreased urine output), as well as a hypertrophic “olive” in the epigastric region and/or a gastric peristaltic wave on examination.

E) CORRECT:

Impaired migration of neural crest cells is the underlying cause of Hirschsprung disease. Parasympathetic neural crest cells migrate in a rostral to caudal direction, from the foregut to the midgut to the hindgut. Failure of the neural crest cells to complete this migration typically results in an aganglionic distal sigmoid and rectum (i.e., without the myenteric and submucosal plexus). As a result, there is hypertonicity in the walls of the rectum and sigmoid, and the internal anal sphincter fails to relax in response to rectal distention. The net effect is intestinal obstruction and dilation of the colon (megacolon). The diagnosis is confirmed via rectal biopsy, which would show aganglionosis, increased acetylcholinesterase activity, and/or hyperplasia of parasympathetic fibers.
Image Description:

The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

F) INCORRECT:

Failure to restore patency to fetal duodenum results in duodenal atresia, which would also present with bilious vomiting and delayed passage of meconium. However, abdominal distention is typically not as prominent, and symptoms are usually evident on the first day after birth with the initiation of feeds. Additionally, the prenatal period is often complicated by polyhydramnios, and an x-ray of the abdomen would show a double bubble sign and absence of gas in the small and large intestine.
Image Description:

X-ray of the abdomen

Dilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

G) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the CFTR gene is the underlying cause of cystic fibrosis, which may result in abdominal distention and bilious vomiting due to intestinal obstruction caused by thickened, inspissated meconium within the distal ileum (meconium ileus). However, x-ray in meconium ileus would typically show small bowel distention or a soap-bubble appearance (Neuhauser sign).
Image Description:

Barium enema (AP view) of a neonate with meconium ileus

Multiple dilated gas-filled loops of small bowel are visible and opaque barium contrast outlines a microcolon (sections of microcolon indicated by green outlines). The findings are consistent with meconium ileus.

Contrast is also seen in multiple locations within the peritoneal space (examples indicated by red overlay) as a result of bowel perforation.

Blue overlay: ECG electrodes
questions.hint: The patient presents with signs of distal intestinal obstruction (delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distention, bilious vomiting), and a DRE shows anal sphincter hypertonicity with an explosive release of stool and air, indicating elevated intraluminal pressure in the colon. X-ray of the abdomen shows megacolon with an area of distal narrowing. These findings are highly suggestive of Hirschsprung disease.
